elements.content: The development of novel photocatalytic systems for energy-saving and efficient water purification and sterilization is extremely challenging but crucial for the prevention of chronic diseases caused by water pollution and bacteria. The self-aggregation of photosensitizers (PSs) driven by tight π–π stacking leads to a sharp decline in the ability to generate reactive oxygen species (ROS) and has become the main bottleneck for the application of PSs in photocatalytic water purification and sterilization. Herein, a series of porous anthracene-based metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) {[Zn­(L)2(DEF)2] n ·2nDEF·nH2O (GXNU-1), [Co2(L)4(DEF)2] n ·4nDEF·8nH2O (GXNU-2), and [Ni­(L)2(DEF)2] n ·nDEF·4nH2O (GXNU-3)} with excellent ROS generation ability were designed and synthesized. The energy level structures of GXNU-1–3 were determined by electrochemical experiments, which proved that all the frameworks have the ability to produce 1O2. In addition, the photocurrent response and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) proved that the formation of MOF structures can effectively enhance the charge separation ability and promote photogenerated holes and excitons under light-driven conditions, thereby further promoting the rapid generation of ROS. Their ability to catalyze the rapid purification and sterilization of high-concentration dye wastewater under low-power (60 mW·cm–2) light irradiation was then determined. The porous framework structure prevents the tight π–π stacking of anthracene-based PSs and increases the contact sites with oxygen. Moreover, the introduction of metal ions promotes the intersystem crossing of excitons through spin–orbit coupling. These advantages greatly enhance the ROS generation ability of GXNU-1–3 in aqueous solutions. Notably, GXNU-1–3 almost completely degraded high-concentration organic dyes, such as crystal violet (CV), methylene blue (MB), rhodamine B (RhB), and orange II (OII). In addition, GXNU-1 efficiently degraded mixed organic dyes of CV (30 mg·L–1) and MB (10 mg·L–1) within 30 min of light irradiation, thereby showing a surprising ability to purify multicomponent dye wastewater. The heterogeneous GXNU-1–3 can be rapidly separated from the aqueous solution by centrifugation and filtration to avoid secondary pollution. More notably, GXNU-1 can effectively inhibit the rapid proliferation of Gram-negative/positive bacteria under light irradiation conditions. Masks and experimental clothes soaked in a GXNU-1 aqueous solution for 15 s clearly resisted bacterial contamination after being exposed to 60 mW·cm–2 light irradiation for 4 min. These findings open new horizons for the construction of novel photocatalytic systems that are fast, efficient, and environmentally friendly.

elements.content: Water pollution has become a major global public health crisis that has caused the disappearance and extinction of species and induced high rates of cancer and disease outbreaks in humans; in particular, water pollution caused by large amounts of dye sewage discharged mainly by the textile industry and bacterial growth is of major concern. Dye sewage with extremely low light transmittance can absorb light and, thus, greatly reduce the transparency of water; it also consumes a large amount of oxygen in the water and contains organic components that have high biological toxicity, which severely damages the self-purification capacity of water, as well as the living environment of aquatic organisms, and has led to potential water scarcity for more than three billion people. Bacterial growth is also an important factor that destroys water environments. Once harmful microorganisms, such as bacteria, enter the water body, the water quality deteriorates, and the water may even emit foul odors, thus endangering human health. Therefore, water pollution prevention and control has become the “new normal.” At present, commonly used water purification treatment methods mainly include physical adsorption and chemical oxidation. Activated carbon is a commonly used adsorbent for physical adsorption; however, it is expensive and has strong use limitations on the purification of moderate or severe water pollution, so it can only be used in lightly polluted water bodies. Meanwhile, the use of chemical oxidation to treat water pollution generally uses a large amount of strong chemical oxidants [Cl2, NaClO, ozone (O3), H2O2, etc.], which results in a large amount of chemical carcinogens remaining in the water and leads to challenging post-treatment. However, increased interest in photocatalysis has led to the development of a series of photosensitive catalysts that have been widely used in photocatalytic water purification; their advantages, such as less secondary pollution, lower operating costs, and the possibility of using sunlight as a reactive light source, have become a new strategy for water purification. So far, these catalysts are mainly based on inorganic semiconductor materials, such as TiO2, CdS, graphene derivatives, Fe2O3, g-C3N4, and their composites. These semiconductor materials can effectively generate photogenerated electron–hole pairs under light irradiation conditions, thereby promoting electron transfer and allowing the generation of type I reactive oxygen species (ROS). These strongly oxidizing free-radical-type (type I) ROS allow applications such as sewage purification and sterilization through redox reactions. A new type of photocatalyststep-scheme heterojunctionhas emerged in recent years, which can effectively achieve the separation of electron–hole pairs with strong redox ability, thereby generating ROS for the further degradation of antibiotics and heavy metals ions. However, dense and solid inorganic semiconductor materials have very low specific surface areas. In addition, their poor dispersibility and water stability in aqueous solutions limit their application.

has strong use limitations on the purification of moderate or severe
water pollution, so it can only be used in lightly polluted water
bodies. Meanwhile, the use of chemical oxidation to treat
water pollution generally uses a large amount of strong chemical oxidants
[Cl2, NaClO, ozone (O3), H2O2, etc.], which results in a large amount of chemical carcinogens
remaining in the water and leads to challenging post-treatment. However, increased interest in photocatalysis has led to the development
of a series of photosensitive catalysts that have been widely used
in photocatalytic water purification; their advantages, such as less
secondary pollution, lower operating costs, and the possibility of
using sunlight as a reactive light source, have become a new strategy
for water purification. So far, these catalysts are mainly based on inorganic semiconductor
materials, such as TiO2, CdS, graphene derivatives, Fe2O3, g-C3N4, and their composites. These semiconductor materials can effectively generate photogenerated
electron–hole pairs under light irradiation conditions, thereby
promoting electron transfer and allowing the generation of type I
reactive oxygen species (ROS). These strongly oxidizing free-radical-type
(type I) ROS allow applications such as sewage purification and sterilization
through redox reactions. A new type of photocatalyststep-scheme

their application.

elements.content: Meanwhile, a class of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with high porosity, large specific surface areas, and tunable pore sizes formed by organic–inorganic hybridization has been widely used in catalysis, gas adsorption, storage, separation, and other fields. In recent years, the eye-catching MOF materials have also seen progress in the fields of sewage purification and sterilization. However, most of these advances remain classical, including the greatly studied traditional MOFs [such as ZIF8, MIL-101-Fe, and MIL-53­(Fe)], which mainly rely on metal centers combined with strong oxidants (H2O2, O3, HClO4, etc.) to generate type I ROS (mainly •OH and •O2 –) through Fenton-like reactions under light irradiation conditions. However, the organic ligands of these classical MOFs have not been utilized or given much attention because they usually require extremely high-energy irradiation to exhibit photocatalytic performance and they consume large amounts of oxidants. In recent years, with the development and expansion of organic photosensitizers (PSs), the introduction of highly photosensitive ligands into MOF materials with high porosity and large specific surface areas have gradually become a popular method of constructing excellent porous photocatalysts. The PS in the porous material structure effectively weakens the fluorescence caused by the tight π–π stacking and the aggregation-caused quenching (ACQ) effect of ROS as a result of the confinement of the pores and cavities. In addition, the high porosity and large specific surface areas of MOFs increase the contact area and catalytic sites for guest molecules, such as oxygen. Finally, the metal center within the structure of photosensitive MOFs can facilitate intersystem crossing (ISC) through the spin–orbit coupling (SOC) effect, thereby resulting in the migration of excitons from the singlet excited state to the triplet excited state through a process called the heavy-atom effect. These aforementioned characteristics jointly contribute to the excellent ROS generation ability and attractive application prospects of MOFs formed by organic PS ligands for sewage purification and sterilization. However, because of limitations in structural design, crystal engineering, and stability, little progress has been made in the use of these MOF materials as ligands in the field of sewage purification and sterilization.

elements.content: In this paper, we report a series of porous anthracene-based MOFs (GXNU-1–3) with excellent ROS generation ability that were designed and synthesized using organic PSs and then applied in energy-saving photocatalytic water purification and sterilization (). GXNU-1–3 were obtained by reacting 9,10-bis­(4-carboxyphenyl)­anthracene with Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O/Co/Ni­(OAc)2·4H2O (the surface areas of GXNU-1–3 were 410.5038, 283.136, and 291.3982 m2/g, respectively, and the pore size distributions of GXNU-1–3 were 15.8723, 8.5906, and 8.6715 nm, respectively,) under solvothermal conditions. The framework structures of GXNU-1–3 effectively prevent the tight π–π stacking of PSs, weaken the ACQ effect of ROS, and result in increased contact areas and active sites with guest molecules, such as oxygen. In addition, metal ions facilitate ISC through SOC, which increases the transfer of more excitons to triplet excited states. The abovementioned advantages jointly contribute to the excellent singlet-oxygen (1O2) generation ability and rate of GXNU-1–3, which has been verified by the obvious 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine oxide (TEMP)-1O2 characteristic EPR signal and the improved (up to 50 times) degradation rate of the diphenylisobenzofuran (DPBF) indicator. In addition, the photocurrent response signal of GXNU-1–3 is much stronger than that of H2L, which proves that the formation of MOF structures can effectively enhance the charge separation ability under light-driven conditions and further promote the rapid generation of ROS. The results of EIS showed that, compared with H2L, the formation of MOF structures also promoted the rapid charge transfer to generate more holes and excitons, thereby enhancing the generation of ROS. It can be calculated that the E g values of GXNU-1–3 are 2.78, 2.75, and 2.78 eV, respectively. In addition, their conduction band (CB) values are −0.31, −0.30, and −0.29 V, respectively, as obtained through the Mott–Schottky curves of GXNU-1–3. Therefore, the valence bands (VB) of GXNU-1–3 are located at 2.48, 2.45, and 2.49 eV, respectively, thereby indicating that they all have the ability to generate 1O2. Moreover, compared with the control group, the experimental group, which contained GXNU-1 under low-power (60 mW·cm–2) light irradiation conditions, showed increased degradation rates (κ) for high concentrations of the single organic dyes crystal violet (CV, 30 mg·L–1), methylene blue (MB, 10 mg·L–1), rhodamine B (RhB, 50 mg·L–1), and orange II (OII, 30 mg·L–1) up to 475, 20, 75, and 150 times, respectively. The κ values for the mixed organic dyes [CV (30 mg·L–1) + MB (10 mg·L–1)] also increased up to 150 and 50 times, respectively. In addition, GXNU-2/3 exhibited excellent degradation properties for CV and MB under the same light irradiation conditions compared with the light-only group, with κ increased by factors of 233.33 and 19.75/7.25, respectively. The excellent ROS generation ability of GXNU-1 also promotes its excellent sterilization efficiency under 4 min of light irradiation conditions. GXNU-1 can be loaded on masks and experimental clothes to resist bacterial contamination. As far as we know, this study is the first to report on a protective mask that has been given the ability to resist bacterial secondary pollution through a very short period of solution immersion. This work provides a novel method for constructing porous photocatalytic water purification and sterilization materials with excellent performance and provides a new strategy for constructing new photocatalytic systems that are efficient and environmentally friendly.

elements.content: A zinc-based MOF {[Zn­(L)2(DEF)2] n ·2nDEF·nH2O, GXNU-1} was synthesized under solvothermal conditions using 9,10-bis­(4-carboxyphenyl)­anthracene (H2L) and Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O. Specifically, 0.2 mmol of H2L (16 mg) and 0.05 mmol of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (16 mg) were accurately weighed and dissolved in an N,N′-diethylformamide (DEF):H2O (v/v = 3:1) mixed solvent and reacted under solvothermal conditions at 100 °C for 72 h to obtain the colorless block crystal GXNU-1 (Figure S1a). Single-crystal X-ray structure diffraction (SCXRD) showed that GXNU-1 crystallized in the monoclinic C 2/c space group (Table S1). GXNU-1 is a porous three-dimensional neutral network structure formed by multiple one-dimensional [Zn­(L)2(DEF)2] n chains formed by the interaction of Zn­(II) ions and H2L through the interaction of strong C–H···O and C–H···π hydrogen bonds (a,b). The infinitely derivatized one-dimensional [Zn­(L)2(DEF)2] n chain with a “W” shape is formed by the deprotonation of the organic ligand H2L and alternate linkage with the second building unit (SBU) ZnO4 (c–e). In the SBU structure, each Zn­(II) ion is coordinated by four oxygen atoms, which are provided by H2L and DEF (two oxygen atoms come from the carboxyl group of H2L, and two oxygen atoms come from DEF), thereby forming a ZnO4 triangular pyramid structure. In addition, two parallel [Zn­(L)2(DEF)2] n chains are linked by C–H···π (3.325 Å) to form a template unit, and multiple template units are further assembled to form a wavy two-dimensional planar structure (c). Finally, the wavy planes are connected by strong C–H···O hydrogen bonds (2.489 Å) to form the porous three-dimensional network framework GXNU-1 (b). The mainframe of the GXNU-1 structure shows electrical neutrality. Notably, the anthracyclines on the PS in the GXNU-1 structure are all clearly dislocated, which effectively avoids the tight π–π stacking between multiple PSs and thereby weakens the notorious fluorescence and ACQ effect of ROS. As shown in g, the distance between dislocated anthracyclines is as long as 9.12 Å, with negligible π–π interactions. SHAPE calculations showed that the coordination configuration of the metal-centered Zn­(II) ion is a seesaw, with a D 2v symmetric environment (h). These uncoordinated saturated L2– ligands and low-coordinated metal-centered Zn­(II) ions are beneficial to the binding and stabilization of guest molecules in the pores. Topological analysis revealed that GXNU-1 can be regarded as an eight-connected fcu network with a distance ranging from 6.92 to 14.31 Å (Figure S1d). Further calculations by Mercury showed that the pore volume of GXNU-1 is as high as 679.67 Å3 (f and S2a); both properties are beneficial for the entry and adsorption of small molecule substrates (such as oxygen and dyes).

elements.content: When Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O was changed to Co/Ni­(OAc)2·4H2O and the ratio of the DEF:H2O mixed solvent was adjusted to 5:1, brown/yellow block crystals were obtained under the same reaction conditions {[Co2(L)4(DEF)2] n ·4nDEF·8nH2O}/{[Ni­(L)2(DEF)2] n ·nDEF·4nH2O, GXNU-2/3} (Figures S1b and S1c). SCXRD showed that GXNU-2 crystallized in the P21/n space group of the monoclinic system, whereas GXNU-3 crystallized in the P1 space group of the triclinic system (Table S1). Although the space groups and metal centers of the GXNU-2/3 crystals are different, they have the same connectivity and topology. Structural analysis of GXNU-2 showed that it can be regarded as a three-dimensional (3D) electrically neutral fishnetlike MOF with diamond-shaped channels formed by L2– as the linker and connected by SBU CoO6 (a). As shown in b,c, although the ligands in the GXNU-2 structure are all in parallel positions, the distance between the anthracyclines on the two ligand layers is as long as 7.97 Å under the confinement of the channel with negligible π–π interactions. In addition, the porosity of GXNU-2 is 15.9%, as calculated by Mercury (d and S2b). GXNU-2 has diamond-shaped channels with lengths of 37.54 Å and widths of 12.89 Å (e). Uncoordinated saturated −COOH and exposed metal sites are present, which are conducive to the confinement catalytic reactions in the pores. The distance between the anthracyclines with dihedral angles of 51.05° is 6.45 Å (f), which largely avoids the tight π–π stacking of the PS ligands in a single unit. Overall, the pores of the rigid GXNU-2 effectively avoid the close packing of the anthracene-derived PS in the aggregated state, thereby greatly weakening the fluorescence of PS in solution, as well as the high quenching of ROS. In addition, the large porosity and pore volume facilitate the entry of small molecule substrates and the adsorption of guest molecules, which allows them to pass through more catalytically active sites. The four vertices of L2– are connected to two CoO6, and the ligand coordination pattern of L2– is μ2-η1:η1:η1:η1 (f). In the SBU structure, each Co­(II) ion is coordinated with six oxygen atoms provided by H2L, DEF, and μ2-O (two oxygen atoms from the carboxyl group of H2L, two oxygen atoms from DEF, and two oxygen atoms from μ2-O), to form a CoO6 octahedral geometry. SHAPE calculations showed that the coordination configuration of the metal-centered Co­(II) ion is an octahedron with an O h symmetric environment (g). Topological analysis revealed that GXNU-2 can be regarded as a six-connected bcu network with a distance ranging from 4.03 to 19.29 Å (Figure S1e).

elements.content: The organic ligands of GXNU-1–3 are all L2–; therefore, their Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) absorption peaks are located at 1300, 1620, and 3600 cm–1 (Figure S3). The broad absorption peak at ∼3600 cm–1 is attributed to the ν­(HO–H) vibration in the H2O molecule. The absorption peak at around 1620 cm–1 is due to the vibration of ν­(CO) in carboxylic acid and ν­(CC) in the benzene ring. The broad absorption peak at 1300 cm–1 is caused by the stretching vibration of ν­(C–O) in the carboxylic acid. GXNU-1–3 were then subjected to thermogravimetric analysis by slowly increasing the temperature from 35 to 1000 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min in a flowing nitrogen atmosphere. The results showed that GXNU-1 underwent two weight loss processes. The weight loss rate below 160 °C was 22.73% and corresponds to the loss of two free DEF guest molecules (theoretical value, 23.07%). The weight loss rate below 300 °C was 3.29% and corresponds to the loss of one water molecule (theoretical value, 2.65%) (Figure S4a). GXNU-2 and 3 also underwent two weight loss processes during the heating process (Figure S4b,c). When the temperature was gradually increased from 35 to 176 °C, the weight loss of GXNU-2 was 11.57%, which corresponds to the loss of two free DEF guest molecules and five free water molecules (theoretical value, 11.62%). When the temperature was gradually increased from 176 to 360 °C, the weight loss rate was 10.62%, which corresponds to the loss of three water molecules and two free DEF guest molecules (theoretical value, 10.19%). The weight loss rate of GXNU-3 below 238 °C was 9.64%, which corresponds to the loss of four free water molecules (theoretical value, 10.55%). The weight loss rate before 373 °C was 12.28%, which is attributed to the loss of one free DEF guest molecule (theoretical value, 12.91%). In addition, the polycrystalline powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) spectra of GXNU-1–3 are highly similar to the simulated spectra, which indicates that all three are pure phases (Figure S5). The scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM) images of GXNU-1–3 clearly show that these MOFs are regular bulk crystals, and the surface of these crystals is very clean (Figures S6 and S7). The results of high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) showed that GXNU-1–3 had obvious lattice fringes, thereby indicating that they all had good crystal states (Figure S8). Adsorption experiments under a nitrogen atmosphere showed that the surface areas of GXNU-1–3 were 410.5038, 283.136, and 291.3982 m2/g (Figure S2c,e,g), respectively, and the pore size distributions of GXNU-1–3 were 15.8723, 8.5906, and 8.6715 nm (Figure S2d,f,h), respectively. These results demonstrate the presence of porosity within the GXNU-1–3 structure.

elements.content: The UV–vis absorption spectra of GXNU-1–3 in pure water/DMSO are shown in a and S9a. GXNU-1–3 consisted of the same photosensitive ligand L2–, which showed characteristic absorption peaks at the same wavelength. In pure water, GXNU-1–3 all showed triple absorption peaks in the 330–420 nm range, with maximum absorption wavelengths of 355, 373, and 394 nm, respectively. In DMSO, GXNU-1–3 also showed triple absorption peaks in the above wavelength range, specifically at 360, 380, and 397 nm, respectively. These triple absorption peaks can all be attributed to the characteristic absorption of the ligands. When the GXNU-1 aqueous/DMSO solution was excited at 380 nm, broad absorption peaks appeared at 400–600 nm, and peaks appeared at 445 and 430 nm (b and S9b). In addition, GXNU-1 exhibited multiple excitation behaviors, as well as weaker excitation shoulders at 364 and 400 nm. When the aqueous GXNU-2 solution was excited at 376 nm, the emission wavelength ranged from 400 to 550 nm, and the highest emission wavelength was 430 nm (c). Similarly, GXNU-3 exhibited a broad emission peak at 441 nm under excitation at 379 nm (c). The emission peak wavelengths of GXNU-2/3 in DMSO did not shift significantly (Figure S9c). GXNU-2 showed significantly stronger excitation and emission than GXNU-3, which indicates that energy transfer may have occurred between the metal ion and the PS ligand (ligand-to-metal charge transfer) (c). These photophysical properties show that GXNU-1–3 efficiently displayed obvious absorption and emission peaks of the PS ligands, thus laying the foundation for their further application. Porous GXNU-1–3 greatly enhanced the ROS of the PS. In addition, the abovementioned porous structure provides more contact space and active sites for guest molecules, such as oxygen and water. Therefore, GXNU-1–3 are expected to show excellent photosensitivity and efficient ROS generation under light irradiation conditions.

elements.content: In order to evaluate the ROS generation ability of GXNU-1–3, we used 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine oxide (TEMP), and 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) was analyzed by electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) as a free radical-trapping reagent. The results showed no obvious EPR signal in TEMP-GXNU-1–3 prior to white light irradiation; however, obvious triple EPR peaks for TEMP-1O2 appeared in TEMP-GXNU-1–3 after light irradiation (e–g). However, no EPR signals for DMPO-•OH and DMPO-•O2 – were observed in DMPO-GXNU-1–3 before and after light irradiation. Therefore, GXNU-1–3 are confirmed to mainly produce singlet oxygen (1O2) through the type II pathway under light irradiation conditions. We further explored the rate of 1O2 generation by GXNU-1–3 using DPBF. As shown in h and S11, the intensity of the characteristic absorption peak (437 nm) corresponding to the 1O2-specific indicator DPBF in the solution containing GXNU-1–3 decreased significantly as the duration of light irradiation increased. After fitting, the rates of degradation of the DPBF solution by GXNU-1–3 were 0.1, 0.07, and 0.07 s–1. In addition, compared with the light group containing only DPBF, the rates of degradation of DPBF by GXNU-1–3 increased by factors of 50, 35, and 35 (i). The absolute fluorescence quantum yield (QY) of GXNU-1 dispersed in the aqueous solution was 11.29%, whereas the QY in DMSO reached 98.13% (Figure S12b,c). Given the sufficient oxygen content in the aqueous solution, a greater number of excitons in the singlet excited state of GXNU-1 reached the triplet excited state through ISC and were finally used to generate 1O2. However, the excitons in the excited state of GXNU-1 in DMSO mainly returned to the ground state through radiative transition (fluorescence), thereby resulting in a high QY (j–l). In addition, we dissolved GXNU-1 in H2O and tested the QY of GXNU-1 under N2 atmosphere. The experimental results show that the QY of GXNU-1 is 90.75% under N2 atmosphere, which proves that after the removal of oxygen, the ISC process of GXNU-1 is inhibited, which results in more excitons returning to the ground state through radiative transitions exhibiting high QY (Figure S12d,e). The fluorescence lifetimes (τ1/e) of GXNU-1 dispersed in the aqueous solution and DMSO are 2.63 and 2.84 ns, respectively, with no significant difference between the two values (Figure S13).

elements.content: In order to further study the mechanism of 1O2 generation by GXNU-1–3, we further explored and analyzed their intrinsic electronic properties and energy transfer process (). First, the charge separation ability of GXNU-1–3 and H2L was investigated by monitoring the photocurrent response generated under light irradiation (a). The results show that the photocurrent response signal of GXNU-1–3 is much stronger than that of H2L, which proves that the formation of three-dimensional and porous MOF structures can effectively enhance the charge separation ability under light-driven conditions and further promote the rapid generation of ROS. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is commonly used to evaluate semiconductor charge-transfer efficiency. As shown in b, compared with the organic ligand H2L, the arc radii of the Nyquist circles observed in GXNU-1–3 are much smaller, which means that these MOF structures can promote the rapid charge transfer to generate more holes and excitons, thereby enhancing the generation of ROS. The energy band gaps (E g) of GXNU-1–3 are calculated on the basis of the results of UV–vis absorption spectra and according to the Kubelck–Munk (K-M) equation. The results show that their E g values are 2.78, 2.75, and 2.78 eV, respectively (c). Additionally, Mott–Schottky diagrams can be used to determine the conduction band (CB) potential and conductivity type of the semiconductors. We tested the Mott–Schottky curves of GXNU-1–3 under the conditions of 500, 1000, and 1500 Hz, respectively, and obtained their CBs as −0.31, −0.30, and −0.29 V, respectively, after fitting (d–f). The results showed that the Mott–Schottky curves of GXNU-1–3 presented positive slopes, which reflected that all three had n-type semiconductor characteristics. Therefore, the valence bands (VB) of GXNU-1–3 are located at 2.48, 2.45, and 2.49 eV, respectively (g). The energy level diagrams of GXNU-1–3 were further drawn, and the results showed that they all had the ability to produce 1O2. All in all, the above results indicate that GXNU-1–3 can effectively promote oxygen to produce 1O2 under light irradiation conditions, and this evidence is also consistent with the EPR results. To further evaluate the photoinduced electron–hole separation, the fluorescence emission spectra of GXNU-1–3 in aqueous solution were measured at different excitation wavelengths of 340, 360, 380, 400, and 420 nm. As shown in Figure S10, at the excitation wavelength of 380 nm, GXNU-1 and -2 exhibit strong fluorescence intensity (λem = 433 nm); at the excitation wavelength of 380 nm, GXNU-3 exhibits strong fluorescence intensity (λem = 422 nm). Notably, almost no fluorescence signal was detected when the excitation wavelength was greater than 400 nm, which indicates that the recombination of charge carriers in aqueous solution was significantly inhibited when GXNU-1–3 was irradiated with visible light. These results collectively confirm that GXNU-1–3 have excellent photogenerated carrier separation ability under visible light irradiation and have great potential as type II photosensitizers.

elements.content: Porous MOFs have been applied in efficient water purification, mainly in the degradation of organic dyes and the removal of heavy metal ions. So far, the porous materials used in water purification are mainly traditional MOFs (such as ZIF8, MIL-101-Fe, and ZIF67), which rely on the Fenton-like reaction of metal centers to generate type I ROS under light irradiation conditions. Although some progress has been made, the organic ligands of these conventional MOFs have not been effectively utilized because they usually require high-energy irradiation to exhibit photocatalytic performance. Therefore, the exploration of MOFs for water purification has mainly focused on type I ROS and has often ignored the potential application of type II ROS. The use of highly photosensitive PSs as ligands in designing and synthesizing MOFs can greatly increase the production of ROS, particularly type II ROS. In addition, these water-immiscible (heterogeneous) MOFs can be effectively and rapidly removed by centrifugation and filtration, thus avoiding secondary pollution. Given that GXNU-1–3 have large pores that facilitate the entry of dye molecules and effectively generate type II ROS under light conditions, we explored the application of GXNU-1–3 in the photocatalytic degradation of different types of organic dyes. Specifically, GXNU-1–3 (0.2 mg·mL–1 concentrations) were added to aqueous solutions containing 10 mg·L–1 organic dyes. Surprisingly, the color of the different organic dye solutions became lighter. The absorption peak intensities of aqueous solutions containing GXNU-1–3 and crystal violet (CV), methylene blue (MB), rhodamine B (RhB), and orange II (OII) significantly decreased, thereby indicating that GXNU-1–3 effectively adsorbed the organic dyes (Figure S14), thus laying the foundation for the excellent photocatalytic degradation performance of these MOFs. Calculations showed that the adsorbed amounts of CV, MB, RhB, and OII by GXNU-1 (1 mg) were 0.05, 0.02, 0.03, and 0.002 mg, respectively (Figure S15). On the basis of the excellent ROS generation ability of GXNU-1–3 under light irradiation conditions and their efficient adsorption of different organic dyes, we selected high concentrations of CV (30 or 20 mg·L–1), MB (10 mg·L–1), RhB (50 mg·L–1), and OII (30 mg·L–1) for the photocatalytic degradation experiments. GXNU-1–3 showed excellent adsorption capacity despite the high concentrations of the aqueous dye solutions. A Xe lamp with a 60 mW·cm–2 power was used to irradiate 100 mL of the aqueous solutions containing the different dyes, and UV–vis absorption spectra were obtained at 0, 5, 10, 15, 20, and 30 min time points (a). GXNU-1 (0.2 mg·L–1) was added to a 30 mg·L–1 aqueous CV solution, and the intensity of the characteristic absorption peak at 580 nm gradually weakened as the duration of light irradiation increased, thereby indicating that GXNU-1 has remarkable photocatalytic degradation efficiency for CV (b). GXNU-1 almost completely degraded the high-concentration CV solution within 30 min, with a degradation amount as high as 97.4%. The degradation of CV conforms to the first-order kinetic equation ln­(C 0/C) = κt, and the calculated rate constant κ of CV photocatalytic degradation by GXNU-1 is 0.19 min–1 (c). However, for the aqueous CV solution without GXNU-1, the degradation was a low 1.3%, and the rate constant κ was 0.0004 min–1 even after irradiation with light of the same power for 30 min. Notably, the introduction of GXNU-1 resulted in a 475-fold increase in the degradation rate of CV, thereby indicating that GXNU-1 has excellent photocatalytic degradation for organic dyes. In addition, when the same GXNU-1 concentration was added to an aqueous solution containing MB (10 mg·L–1), OII (30 mg·L–1), and RhB (50 mg·L–1) under the same power and light irradiation conditions, GXNU-1 showed an excellent degradation ability of 95.2%, 76.5%, and 93%, respectively, and almost completely degraded the organic dyes within 30 min (d,f,h). The degradation rates κ of GXNU-1 for MB, OII, and RhB were 0.08, 0.03, and 0.15 min–1, respectively (e,g,i). The degradation rates κ of the dyes in the aqueous MB, OII, and RhB control solutions were 0.004, 0.0004, and 0.001 min–1, respectively. After the introduction of GXNU-1, the degradation rates of the dyes increased by factors of 20, 75, and 150, respectively. These results indicate that GXNU-1 exhibited excellent degradation ability against a single organic dye in an aqueous solution. However, a variety of organic dyes often exist in daily sewage. Therefore, 0.2 mg·L–1 GXNU-1 was added to an aqueous solution containing the mixed dyes CV (30 mg·L–1) and MB (10 mg·L–1). As the illumination time was increased from 0 to 30 min, the absorbance of CV and MB decreased from 4.92 and 2.57 (a.u.) to 0.53 and 0.45 (a.u.), respectively (a). The amounts of GXNU-1-degraded CV and MB in the mixed dye were 89.2% and 82.5%, respectively, and the degradation rates κ were 0.06 and 0.05 min–1, respectively (b,c). The rate constants κ of the pure CV and MB aqueous solution irradiation groups were 0.0004 and 0.001 min–1, respectively, whereas those of the aqueous CV and MB solution irradiation groups containing GXNU-1 were 150 and 50 times higher, respectively. Overall, GXNU-1 showed excellent photocatalytic degradation effects on a variety of organic dyes, and all of them were almost completely degraded in aqueous solutions within 30 min. However, the organic dye in the solution of the blank control group (without GXNU-1) showed no obvious change under the same light irradiation (Figure S16). The dislocation stacking of anthracycline on the photosensitive ligand in the GXNU-1 structure weakens the tight π–π stacking, and the heavy metal Zn­(II) ion inside the structure promotes ISC. Together, these two phenomena enhanced the 1O2 generation to achieve an excellent photocatalytic water purification effect.

elements.content: Similarly, 0.2 mg·mL–1 GXNU-2/3 solutions were added to aqueous solutions containing CV (20 mg·L–1) and MB (10 mg·L–1) under the same light irradiation conditions, and the UV–vis absorption spectra were obtained. The experimental results show that GXNU-2/3 both exhibited excellent photocatalytic degradability for CV (85.5%, GXNU-2; 81.7%, GXNU-3) and MB (88.1%, GXNU-2; 62.5%, GXNU-3). Both GXNU-2 and -3 were able to significantly degrade aqueous solutions containing CV and MB within 30 min (). As calculated using ln­(C 0/C) = κt, the rate constant κ of GXNU-2/3 photocatalytic degradation of CV is 0.07 min–1, whereas those for MB are 0.079 and 0.029 min–1, respectively (). The degradation rate constant κ of the aqueous solutions containing only added CV or MB under light irradiation conditions were 0.0003 and 0.004 min–1, respectively, and the organic dye CV or MB degradation rates of the experimental group containing GXNU-2/3 increased by factors of 233.33, 19.75, and 7.25, respectively. All in all, GXNU-2/3 exhibited excellent photocatalytic degradation effects on aqueous CV and MB solutions. The organic dyes in the solution of the blank control group (without GXNU-2/3) did not change significantly under the same light irradiation conditions (Figure S16), thereby indicating that GXNU-2/3 are excellent light-catalytic sewage purification systems. So far, most of the reported photocatalytic dye degradation studies have shown degraded organic dye aqueous solutions at 10 mg·L–1 concentrations, whereas GXNU-1–3 not only showed the ability to degrade 10 mg·L–1 aqueous organic dye solutions efficiently, they also exhibited significant degradation effects on organic dye aqueous solutions with high concentrations (20–50 mg·L–1). In addition, we selected GXNU-1 for multiple photocatalytic degradation experiments involving the organic dye MB. GXNU-1 maintained excellent degradation performance even after four cycles (Figure S17).

elements.content: In order to further verify the stability of GXNU-1–3 after dye degradation. PXRD, SEM, TEM and HR-TEM tests were performed on GXNU-1–3 after dye degradation (Figures S18–S21). The results showed that the PXRD spectra of GXNU-1–3 used for dye degradation were highly like the theoretical values of the structures, thereby indicating that GXNU-1–3, after the degradation of organic dyes, still maintained high stability (Figure S18). The morphologies of GXNU-1–3 after photocatalytic dye degradation were further tested by SEM and TEM, and the results showed that these MOFs still maintained a stable morphology after degrading the dye, and there was no significant change compared with the original crystal samples (Figures S19 and S20). In addition, it was observed in the HR-TEM images that GXNU-1–3 after photocatalytic dye degradation still had obvious lattice fringes, thereby indicating that their crystalline states had not been lost (Figure S21). Therefore, the above experimental results indicate that GXNU-1–3 still maintain high stability after photoirradiation degradation of organic dyes. In addition, we soaked GXNU-1–3 in high-concentration RhB aqueous solution (100 mg·L–1), soaked them for 12 h, and then filtered out GXNU-1–3 (Figure S22a–c) and washed the MOFs with pure water three times to ensure that the surfaces of GXNU-1–3 were clean. Subsequently, the cleaned GXNU-1–3 were put into pure water for ultrasonication for 1 h. It is worth noting that the color of the pure aqueous solution after sonication changed from colorless to pink (Figure S22e). Furthermore, we carried out the UV–vis absorption spectrum test on the aqueous solution after the dye was released by GXNU-1–3 under ultrasonic conditions. The experimental results show that the aqueous solutions of GXNU-1–3 after ultrasonication have absorption peaks at 553 nm, and their absorption values are 0.76, 0.66, and 0.63 (a.u.) (Figure S22d). Therefore, it was proved that the dye molecules entered the pores of GXNU-1–3. All these experimental results indicate that GXNU-1–3 can be used as excellent photocatalytic systems for the purification of complex dye wastewater. This work provides a new strategy for constructing MOF materials with excellent photocatalytic sewage purification performance.

elements.content: The cause of death of about 7.7 million people in the world is related to infections by bacterial pathogens because bacterial infection can induce various diseases and pose a serious threat to human health. In addition, domestic sewage usually contains many bacterial pathogens that are characterized by wide distribution, long survival, and rapid reproduction. If sewage water cannot be treated in time for long-term drinking or eating, organisms can accumulate as pathogens in human bodies and may induce cancer. Given the structural advantages of GXNU-1 and its ability to effectively generate a large amount of ROS under light conditions, we chose two common Gram-positive/negative bacteriaStaphylococcus aureus and Escherichia colito explore the bacterial inactivation assay of GXNU-1 (a). Each strain was recovered in a biochemical incubator at 37 °C for approximately 24 h, inoculated in an LB liquid medium for culture, and finally diluted with 0.9% (w/v) normal saline to prepare the bacterial suspension as a 0.5 McMahon turbidity standard (∼2 × 108 cfu·mL–1) for later use. The GXNU-1 doses in each control group were 0, 0.625, 1.25, 2.5, and 5 mg·mL–1, respectively. The light irradiation experiment group was irradiated for 4 min under a Xe lamp with a power of 60 mW·cm–2 and then transferred to a biochemical incubator at 37 °C for 24 h. The experimental results showed that both the light group and the dark group with 0 mg·mL–1 of GXNU-1 had no obvious inactivation ability against S. aureus and E. coli (b,c). Bacteria within the light irradiation range (red dotted circle) were effectively inactivated. In addition, as the GXNU-1 concentration gradually increased, the bactericidal effect was also significantly enhanced. The 5 mg·mL–1 of GXNU-1 showed the greatest bactericidal and sterilizing effects on S. aureus under light irradiation, reaching approximately 95%. Therefore, GXNU-1 can also be used as a class of excellent photocatalytic sterilizers. In order to further reveal the antibacterial mechanism, we observed the morphological changes of E. coli only treated with light (Xe lamp, 60 mW·cm–2) and light-treated after adding GXNU-1 by SEM. The experimental results showed that the E. coli in the light-irradiated group was smooth and plump and had a complete shape, which indicated that it had good viability. However, in the presence of GXNU-1 and after light irradiation, the surface of E. coli was obviously shrunken and ruptured, and the morphology was damaged to varying degrees, which indicated that the ROS produced by GXNU-1 could effectively kill E. coli (pointed out by the yellow arrow) (Figure S24).

elements.content: The 2019 novel coronavirus pneumonia (coronavirus disease 2019, COVID-19) came suddenly and has posed a serious threat to human public health and safety. Since COVID-19 can be transmitted through the respiratory tract and respiratory droplets, medical protective equipment, such as masks and protective clothing, which can protect individuals from COVID-19, have become essential during the global epidemic. However, traditional medical protective equipment only intercepts germs through physical barriers and lacks the ability to kill germs. Eventually, germs can reproduce and breed in large numbers on medical protective equipment, thereby causing secondary pollution to daily life and greatly increasing virus cross-infection and transmission. Therefore, people are eager to develop medical protective equipment that can block the breeding and cross-spreading of germs by completely killing the microorganisms. The high-porosity GXNU-1 is a good candidate for protection against the spread of living bacteria. Therefore, we attached GXNU-1 to masks and experimental clothes to determine its sterilizing effects. The culture and concentration of the bacteria used were the same as those in the experiments, and 100 μL of S. aureus liquid was evenly spread on a Listeria Chromogenic Agar (LA) medium. Masks and experimental clothes cut to 5 × 5 or 3 × 3 cm2 pieces were soaked in an aqueous solution containing 5 mg·mL–1 of GXNU-1, taken out after 15 s, and added to the LA medium coated with S. aureus. The light experiment group was placed under a Xe lamp with a power of 60 mW·cm–2 for 4 min and then placed in a biochemical incubator at 37 °C for 24 h (a). The experimental results showed that S. aureus was not observed on the masks and experimental clothes of the light group, whereas the masks and experimental clothes of the blank and dark groups were covered with bacteria (b and S23), thereby indicating that bacterial growth was not inhibited at all. Therefore, GXNU-1 can be used in the raw materials of personal protective equipment to prevent the spread of bacteria. Notably, although only a small amount of GXNU-1 was placed on the masks and experimental clothes after soaking for a short period, the soaked masks and clothes still experienced a highly efficient photocatalytic bactericidal effect. The catalytic sites of the highly porous GXNU-1 generate a large amount of type II 1O2 that inactivate bacteria. Thus, GXNU-1 has great potential application in the development of new reusable protective equipment.
elements.clean_text:
The 2019 novel coronavirus pneumonia (coronavirus
disease 2019,
COVID-19) came suddenly and has posed a serious threat to human public
health and safety. Since COVID-19 can be transmitted through the respiratory
tract and respiratory droplets, medical protective equipment, such
as masks and protective clothing, which can protect individuals from
COVID-19, have become essential during the global epidemic. However, traditional medical protective equipment only intercepts
germs through physical barriers and lacks the ability to kill germs.
Eventually, germs can reproduce and breed in large numbers on medical
protective equipment, thereby causing secondary pollution to daily
life and greatly increasing virus cross-infection and transmission.
Therefore, people are eager to develop medical protective equipment
that can block the breeding and cross-spreading of germs by completely
killing the microorganisms. The high-porosity GXNU-1 is
a good candidate for protection against the spread of living bacteria.
Therefore, we attached GXNU-1 to masks and experimental
clothes to determine its sterilizing effects. The culture and concentration
of the bacteria used were the same as those in the experiments, and
100 μL of S. aureus liquid was evenly spread
on a Listeria Chromogenic Agar (LA) medium. Masks and experimental
clothes cut to 5 × 5 or 3 × 3 cm2 pieces were
soaked in an aqueous solution containing 5 mg·mL–1 of GXNU-1, taken out after 15 s, and added to the LA
medium coated with S. aureus. The light experiment
group was placed under a Xe lamp with a power of 60 mW·cm–2 for 4 min and then placed in a biochemical incubator
at 37 °C for 24 h (a). The experimental results showed that S. aureus was not observed on the masks and experimental clothes of the light
group, whereas the masks and experimental clothes of the blank and
dark groups were covered with bacteria (b and S23), thereby
indicating that bacterial growth was not inhibited at all. Therefore, GXNU-1 can be used in the raw materials of personal protective
equipment to prevent the spread of bacteria. Notably, although only
a small amount of GXNU-1 was placed on the masks and
experimental clothes after soaking for a short period, the soaked
masks and clothes still experienced a highly efficient photocatalytic
bactericidal effect. The catalytic sites of the highly porous GXNU-1 generate a large amount of type II 1O2 that inactivate bacteria. Thus, GXNU-1 has great
potential application in the development of new reusable protective
equipment.

elements.content: We designed and synthesized a series of metal–organic frameworks with excellent ROS generation ability and efficient photocatalytic purification and sterilization of high-concentration dye wastewater. The high porosity and large pores greatly weaken the close packing of the PS ligands in the aggregated state, as well as increase the contact area and catalytic sites for guest molecules, such as oxygen. Metal ions promote excitons from the singlet excited state to the triplet excited state through ISC via the SOC effect. The combined effects of the aforementioned factors have led to the excellent 1O2 generation ability of GXNU-1–3, which was verified by the EPR results of TEMP-1O2 and the degradation of the DPBF indicator. Compared with H2L, the formation of MOF structures can enhance their ability to produce 1O2, and their energy level structure also verifies this. Under low-power Xe lamp irradiation, GXNU-1 showed degradation abilities against high-concentration CV, MB, OII, and RhB, with degradation amounts reaching 97.4%, 95.2%, 76.5%, and 93%, respectively, within 30 min. Compared with the light-only control group, the degradation rates κ of CV, MB, OII, and RhB by GXNU-1 increased by factors of 475, 20, 75, and 150, respectively. In addition, GXNU-1 almost completely degraded CV and MB in the mixed dye within 30 min, thereby showing excellent photocatalytic complex dye sewage purification performance. Similarly, GXNU-2/3 had excellent degradation performance for high concentrations of CV and MB under the same light irradiation conditions. GXNU-1–3 can be quickly removed from the aqueous solution by centrifugation and filtration, thus avoiding secondary pollution. The abovementioned excellent colored sewage purification ability is mainly derived from the efficient ROS generation of GXNU-1–3, which also promotes the potential application of GXNU-1–3 in the field of sterilization. GXNU-1 showed excellent sterilizing effects against S. aureus and E. coli after irradiation for 4 min under a 60 mW·cm–2 Xe lamp. In addition, protective masks and experimental clothes soaked in an aqueous GXNU-1 solution for 15 s effectively resisted bacterial contamination under light irradiation. This work has developed a high-efficiency, low-energy, and environment-friendly photocatalytic system for dye wastewater purification, which opens new horizons for precise structural designs, optimized crystal engineering strategies, and improved catalyst structure designs. In addition, this work provides an example of a high-efficiency sterilant that can prevent secondary bacterial contamination, thus providing a new method of designing and developing medical protective equipment.
